skill.name: code-analysis
skill.description: Check if code is readable by non-developers - clear names, plain English comments, no jargon
skill.summary: Check if code is readable by non-developers - clear names, plain English comments, no jargon
skill.author: abereyes

security_audit.summary: This is a straightforward code readability analyzer with minimal risk. It only reads files specified by the user via command-line arguments, uses standard Python libraries for parsing, and makes no network requests. The capabilities match its stated purpose of checking code accessibility.

content.value_statement: Code often contains cryptic names and technical jargon that non-developers cannot understand. This skill analyzes your code and scores how accessible it is to managers, stakeholders, and new team members.
actual_capabilities: Detects cryptic variable and function names that need clarification
Flags unexplained technical jargon in code comments
Verifies What/Why/How documentation for functions and classes
Scores code readability from 0-100 with detailed issues
limitations: Only analyzes Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, Java, Go, Ruby, and PHP files
May produce false positives in documentation-heavy files
Does not modify code - only reports issues

use_cases.title: Audit team codebases
use_cases.description: Review code readability scores across your codebase to identify documentation gaps and unclear naming patterns.

use_cases.title: Onboard new team members
use_cases.description: Ensure code is accessible to new hires who may not have deep programming experience.

use_cases.title: Review stakeholder code
use_cases.description: Check configuration scripts and automation code for clarity before sharing with non-technical stakeholders.

prompt_templates.title: Basic check
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the code-analysis skill to check readability of my_file.py

prompt_templates.title: Strict analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze my_script.ts with strict mode to find all naming and documentation issues

prompt_templates.title: Specific focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Check only the variable naming in config.rb using the code-analysis skill

prompt_templates.title: Full report
prompt_templates.prompt: Run a full readability audit on my project directory and output JSON results

output_examples.input: Analyze the readability of my authentication module
output: Missing Comments: 1 issue (12 lines without explanation)
Unexplained Jargon: 2 issues (API, JWT without definitions)

best_practices: Run the analyzer before sharing code with non-technical stakeholders
Use lenient mode when first addressing readability to avoid overwhelming output
Address cryptic naming issues first as they affect comprehension most
anti_patterns: Ignoring low scores without reviewing specific issues
Using the tool on generated code or boilerplate without context
Focusing only on score rather than understanding each issue type

faq.question: Which programming languages are supported?
faq.answer: Python, JavaScript, TypeScript, Java, Go, Ruby, and PHP files are supported.

faq.question: What readability score is considered good?
faq.answer: Scores above 75 indicate good readability. Above 90 is excellent and accessible to most non-developers.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with CI/CD pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, use the --format json flag to get machine-readable output for automated pipelines.

faq.question: Is my code data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. The analyzer runs locally and makes no network requests. Your code never leaves your machine.

faq.question: Why are legitimate abbreviations flagged?
faq.answer: The tool flags abbreviations like usr or tkn that non-developers cannot understand. Standard terms like num or str are allowed.

faq.question: How is this different from linters?
faq.answer: Linters enforce syntax and style rules. This tool focuses on human comprehension - whether non-developers can understand the code logic and purpose.
